answers.answer: Just because your labs were in the so-called "normal" range does not mean that all is okay there.  The ranges are far too broad to be functional for many people.  Please post those lab results and reference ranges and members will be better able to comment on your testing and diagnosis.

for your TSH, what is your doctor considering "normal" Is he/she showing you the results? If you feeel your doctor is not doing enough for you, you should ask to be reffered to an endo, if your doctor hesitates or gives excuses, demand it or go to the emerge with the worst of your symptoms and have them reffer you to one.

Just because a doctor is an Endo does not mean a good thyroid doctor.  Many of them specialize in diabetes, not thyroid.  Many others have the "Immaculate TSH Belief" and only go by TSH, which doesn't work.  Many others use "Reference Range Endocrinology", by which they will tell a patient that a test result that falls anywhere within the reference range is adequate.  That is also wrong.A good thyroid doctor will treat a hypo patient clinically by testing and adjusting Free T3 and Free T4 as necessary to relieve symptoms, without being constrained by resultant TSH levels.  Symptom relief is what really matters to the patient, not just test results and especially not just TSH results.It is very unfortunate that the  AACE (Amer. Association of CLINICAL Endocrinologists) doesn't really live up to its name and treat clinically, rather than as described above.  Maybe they should consider a name change.  LOL

My TSH is 0.70 , range is 	0.35 - 5.5 uIU/ml,    My free T3 is 3.1, range is 2.3 - 4.2 pg/ml,    My free T4 is 1.31, range used is 0.9 - 1.8 ng/dl.I feel if everything were normal I wouldn't have several goiters.  Due to all other medical issues and classic symptoms for thyroid problems I am at a loss.  An ENT is the first Dr. I saw who I at the time worked for felt the goiters, ordered an ultrasound, and bloodwork but only TSH.  I tried seeing my GP this time but not confident he is knowledgeable enough about thyroids.  I did look up Endos in my area and only found one who list anything about thyroids but his main is diabetes.Any suggestions?

question: My question is kinda long to give background hope not to long.I was found to have several goiters on both sides of my thyroid last year, because of me complaining of the being choked feeling.  A TSH was normal at that time.  That choking feeling has now returned and find it difficult to swallow solid foods.  Again TSH, Free T3, and Free T4 were "normal". Seeing more and more of my scalp(hair loss), but nails fine, fatigue at least once a day to the point I feel like I am going to pass out.  In this last year I have been diagnosed with GERD, Barrett's, Lichen Sclerosis, DDD, and gut issues.  All being studied to be linked to auto immune.  I find my symptoms to be worse in the evening with all.Any suggestions on what I should be doing or having done next?Tanya
title: frustrated
